1. Write your notes, rather than type them up
2. Sleep
3. Exercise to increase your focus
4. Mnemonics: the sillier the sentence, the better, as you will remember it! GBDFA = Grizzly bears don't fly airplanes
5. Drink water: 500ml
6. Reward yourself. Try a ratio 3:1. Work 3 times as much as play.

6) be hydrated

Best tips to study
1•Find a quiet room or go to the library. Not with friends.
2•Keep your phone outside of your room with the mute mode.
3•Pack your bag with fruit/snacks and water/juice and with copies, pouch.
4. Don't have heavy meals before studying.
5. Don't sit after a table fan as you can feel sleepy.
6. Read one chapter every day.
7. Don't listen to music, it distracts. Listen relaxing and motivating music.

8.Study for 25 minute and 5-minute time pass.
9.Practice.If not able to learn to write it at least 1 time.
10. Highlight important points and decorate your copy with colors and pens.Write in good writing so you will want to study.


Tips to study before exams.
1. Read many times and you will be able to learn it.
2. Don't revise at the last minute.
3. Don't cram, understand.
4. Don't study at night as you will feel sleepy and not able to learn anything.Have sufficient sleep.
5. Don't move here and there.Keep all the things with you at the desk.
6. Make a planner and checklists. Keep important paper with you
7. Take a timed test.
8. Don't study on a sofa or a bed. Study while walking or on a chair
9. Speak it loudly.
10.Not able to learn to listen to it several times by recording it.

To remember the difference between α and β sugars (this applies to the -OH group on the last C atom in the sugar), I used to seme/uke >> omegaverse thing.

Where, we always assume that α's are always semes in the omegaverse and β's are ukes. Semes are 'top' and ukes are 'bottom', this is a sort of esablished fact, right?

Except it's different for sugars. You see β's are always the top, and α's are always the bottom. So of the -OH group is below on the last C atom in the sugar compound, that means its an uke, but sugars are different from omegaverse so it's an α-sugar.

Since no one uses type writers anymore. But, I feel like people from England still have those type writers persevered. Type writers seems less distracting than modern laptops and computers.

Writing a few times is equivalent to reading several times. So I’m aware that we all text message, and type so frequent. But I’m trying to get myself to write as much I can.

Since I do not like wasting paper. Just use back side of the paper as scrap paper or drawing. Also for organization use a folder, binder or expanding file folder (accordion).

But, I do believe hearing a lot of handwriting benefits by writing in your own handwriting than typing. Writing in your own handwriting actually helps retain the information.

When it comes to using a type writer, I rather write in my own handwriting, proof read for grammar, spelling, sentence structure, word choice, and ways to polish my writing. Once I have everything done, I will copy by typing just so I have the original, and the typed version of my writing. It feels more effective and clearer.

As for letters, I’m aware everyone can still write letters and mail them to your friends or someone that is closest to them. But, proof reading for your grammar, spelling, word usage, and sentence structure, especially punctuation is important. I’m thankful for having an education. So the best way to retain information is writing in your own hand writing.

Mnemonics certainly work, but then you've got to reach the information via the mnemonic.  I made a stupid mnemonic to remember all the countries in Central America, but I can only reach those countries by working through the mnemonic.  By contrast, I learned Sin: Side-opposite over hypotenuse, Cos: Adjacent over hypotenuse, Tan: Side-opposite over adjacent; and have direct access to the formula.  Much more satisfying.
Learning in the evening before bed DOES aid retention.  But it's not as simple as that: you've also got to CARE about the stuff you're learning to get those benefits.

I agree with many things in the video, but the stuff about not using a computer depends how you use it. If you paste from a web-page into a document, of course there's going to be no retention. But if you re-frame the information while TYPING it, and read aloud what you're typing; and then use what you've typed in any of a myriad of different ways to reinforce your learning, it's going to be effective.

I challenge anyone reading this, to reference a decent study which has tested typing notes vs than writing them, using the same best-practice techniques for both typing and writing, and using the the various options available for continued learning reinforcement available with each technique, to provide a quantity of retention against time invested.

I have recently been learning a language and have not written more than a handful of words on paper in the target language. After a year, my teacher says I'm learning faster than anyone he's taught before. Of course the plural of anecdote is not data, but neither have I seen any data that has made a fair test. (Admission: sure, I've not looked very hard.)

Scientific research also points that extrinsic rewards may backfire dramatically, as it can erode an intrinsic motivation in the task. It's as if part of you, unconsciously, were thinking "well, if the conscious part of me has to reward me for doing it, that's probably something I don't like to do, even though I kind of thought I liked, so I guess I'll push for higher short-term rewards from now on, and do whatever else in the absence of rewards". It applies for tasks in general but I think there has been some research focused specifically on rewards for studying.

This is misleading. The sleep study that is presented here is deemed invalid due to confounding variables. Group 2 for example has studied only with a sleep break, whereas group 1 must have had other activities during the day in between study sessions. It is very likely that interference by the other activities caused/or could cause loss of retention. So another set up of that study is needed.

I think for the study-sleep-study, it's the study-sleep part that makes the difference.  When we sleep our brains essentially does a clean disk + defrag with the information it took in that day.  Information from earlier in the day is more likely to be dumped while information later in the day is more likely to be retained.  Likely due to the memories being "fresh" and therefore stronger.

I got another good set of tips for those who find reading school textbooks boring. Keep in mind that you will be reading back to front first:


1.) Read the questions found at the end of the chapter and try to answer them all
This will warm up your brain to retain information better, especially for key bits you need to learn. Don't worry about being wrong.
2.) Read the Chapter Summary (yes, not the beginning of the chapter)
You'll get a... wait for it... a summary of what to expect in the chapter, so you know what you'll be learning about.
3.) Read the headings and subheadings of the chapter
You'll now get specific ideas of what you will be reading and where to look for specific answers.
4.) Read the chapter introduction
This is the point where you read front to back of a chapter. Be sure you are taking notes (on paper), and create one sentence that summarizes every paragraph.

Using these tips, you'll connect bits of info more strongly together than just reading it normally at first.

"First Step is skip the laptop. Although you might be at typing, writing with pen and paper..."

Um, I used laptops that were once called tablets and then were labelled 'convertable PCs' - these had Wacom digitizers in them and, when combined with Windows Journal, was just like writing in a notebook but with the advantages of digital file storage (so much easier to carry one laptop than several notebooks and textbooks).

Sadly, even though I used these for almost a decade and a half, no one seemed to be aware that they existed. They're as hard to find as laptops with decent dedicated graphics. (Had to get an android tablet as I couldn't find what I need - man do I miss using animation software on a laptop that let me draw directly to the screen.) So its not no laptop, its hand write your notes.

(Also, yes, I do like being the one who usually is that statistical outlier that researchers have to throw out of their studies.)

Taking down written notes in your own words only seems viable when your professor isn't teaching at mach 5. It's for this reason some students record their professors so they can re-listen to lectures afterwords. If you can take written notes that will help you retain information, go for it, but I also suggest trying to just sit there and listen to what the professor is saying instead. Sometimes writing is enough distraction to make you miss the subtleties in what's being taught.

Another tip would be to create a small lesson plan as to how you would teach what you just learned. Understanding a topic is good but to teach it is mastery. Try formatting your "lesson plan" in the same way asapSCIENCE does it in which it's easy to understand and can be explain to a 10 year old.

Notes are not conclusively better than laptops. Laptops don't make you process the information at a shallower level.

Notes are correlated with better performance, because you physically cannot write what a someone is saying, while you can type everything that someone is saying, provided that there are enough pauses.

It's not that laptops are bad for taking notes, it's that the note taker doesn't apply good note-taking techniques, because they are distracting themselves with the amount of notes that they are taking.

It's correlated, not causal. It's predicted that we'll see a shift, once schools begin applying technology in a different way.
